case_name: Union of India v. sons and widow of Babu Ram and Triveni Kala Sangam

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 322 of 1960 was filed by special leave.

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated November 21, 1957 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in L.P.A. No. 4 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 322 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1957, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in L.P.A. No. 4 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 29, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by special leave is preferred against the judgment of a division bench of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi

facts.text: Babu Ram was the owner of Flat No. 5, Aggarwal Building, Connaught Circus, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: One Babu Ram was the owner of Flat No. 5, Aggarwal Building, Connaught Circus, New Delhi respondents 1 to 6 are his sons-and widow. By an order dated April 14, 1943, the Government of India requisitioned the said flat under r.75- A 1  of the Defence of India Rules for a period of one year from April 15, 1943. to April 14, 1944.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 6 are sons and widow of Babu Ram.

anchor.surface_text: New Delhi respondents 1 to 6 are his sons-and widow. By an order dated April 14, 1943, the Government of India requisitioned the said flat under r.75- A 1  of the Defence of India Rules for a period of one year from April 15, 1943. to April 14, 1944.

facts.text: Flat requisitioned by Government of India on April 14, 1943 under r.75-A(1) of Defence of India Rules for one year from April 15, 1943 to April 14, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated April 14, 1943, the Government of India requisitioned the said flat under r.75- A 1  of the Defence of India Rules for a period of one year from April 15, 1943. to April 14, 1944. The said flat was put in the occupation of one Hardie of the Indian National Airways.

facts.text: Flat occupied by Hardie of Indian National Airways.

anchor.surface_text: The said flat was put in the occupation of one Hardie of the Indian National Airways. The period of requisition was extended from time to time, and finally by an order dated April 2, 1946, the flat was requisitioned from April 15, 1946, until further orders of the Central Government.

facts.text: Requisition extended finally by order dated April 2, 1946 from April 15, 1946 until further orders.

anchor.surface_text: The period of requisition was extended from time to time, and finally by an order dated April 2, 1946, the flat was requisitioned from April 15, 1946, until further orders of the Central Government. After Mr. Hardie vacated the flat, it was allotted to other officers.

facts.text: After Hardie vacated, flat allotted to other officers.

anchor.surface_text: After Mr. Hardie vacated the flat, it was allotted to other officers. Babu Ram requested the Government from time to time to de-requisition the said flat for his personal use.

facts.text: Babu Ram requested de-requisition due to heart trouble, indifferent health, two sons married, small house in narrow lane.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Ram requested the Government from time to time to de-requisition the said flat for his personal use. He represented that he was suffering from heart trouble and was companytinuously keeping indifferent health, that two of his sons had got married, and that in those circumstances it had become impossible for him to companytinue to live in their small house in a narrow lane

facts.text: Government rejected Babu Ram's request for de-requisition.

anchor.surface_text: but the Government of India rejected his request on the ground that on surrender by the officers of the Indian National Airways it would be required for allotment to Central Government officers. Babu Ram died on October, 24, 1951.

facts.text: Babu Ram died on October 24, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Ram died on October, 24, 1951. It appears that four or five months in 1947 the flat was vacant and thereafter it was occupied by refugees from West Pakistan.

facts.text: Flat vacant for four or five months in 1947, then occupied by refugees from West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that four or five months in 1947 the flat was vacant and thereafter it was occupied by refugees from West Pakistan. It was afterwards given to the present respondent No. 7, Triveni Kala Sangam.

facts.text: Flat given to respondent No. 7, Triveni Kala Sangam.

anchor.surface_text: It was afterwards given to the present respondent No. 7, Triveni Kala Sangam. On November 4,1952, respondent No. 1 again requested the Government to de- requisition the flat mainly on the ground that the said flat was number in use of the officers of the Central Government but was put in possession of Triveni Kala Sangam, which was a private dance and music school.

facts.text: Triveni Kala Sangam is a private dance and music school.

anchor.surface_text: the said flat was number in use of the officers of the Central Government but was put in possession of Triveni Kala Sangam, which was a private dance and music school. As numberreply was given to that request, the said respondent sent a reminder on June 26, 1953,

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 requested de-requisition on November 4, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On November 4,1952, respondent No. 1 again requested the Government to de- requisition the flat mainly on the ground that the said flat was number in use of the officers of the Central Government but was put in possession of Triveni Kala Sangam,

facts.text: Reminder sent on June 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: As numberreply was given to that request, the said respondent sent a reminder on June 26, 1953, and to that he received a reply to the effect that the matter is receiving attention and further companymunication will follow in due companyrse.

facts.text: Government replied that matter receiving attention.

anchor.surface_text: and to that he received a reply to the effect that the matter is receiving attention and further companymunication will follow in due companyrse. On September 16, 1953, the Government informed the first respondent that he companyld execute a lease deed in favour of the Government in respect of the said flat.

facts.text: On September 16, 1953, Government informed respondent to execute lease deed.

anchor.surface_text: On September 16, 1953, the Government informed the first respondent that he companyld execute a lease deed in favour of the Government in respect of the said flat. As the appellants did number put the respondents in possession of the said flat, they had numberalternative but to file a petition for a writ of mandamus in the High Court of Punjab.

facts.text: Falshaw, J. issued writ of mandamus on October 19, 1954 directing appellants to put respondents in possession.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard by Falshaw, J., and the learned Judge issued a writ of mandamus on October 19, 1954, directing the appellants to put the respondents in possession of the flat. Against the said order, on November 26, 1954, the appellants filed a Letters Patent appeal in the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi.

facts.text: Letters Patent appeal filed on November 26, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Against the said order, on November 26, 1954, the appellants filed a Letters Patent appeal in the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi. The appeal was filed within 30 days from the date of the said order after excluding the time taken for obtaining certified companyies of the necessary documents but more than 20 days thereafter.

facts.text: Division bench dismissed appeal on November 21, 1957 holding appeal out of time and on merits.

anchor.surface_text: confirming that of a single Judge of that High Court issuing a writ of mandamus against the Union of India directing it to restore possession of the flat requisitioned by the said Government to the respondents.

facts.text: Appeal filed within 30 days excluding time for certified copies but more than 20 days thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was filed within 30 days from the date of the said order after excluding the time taken for obtaining certified companyies of the necessary documents but more than 20 days thereafter. The appeal was heard by a division bench of the said. High Court companysisting of the Chief Justice and Mehar Singh, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Letters Patent appeal within time under r.4.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that under r. 4 an appeal companyld be filed within 30 days from the date of the order of Falshaw, J., and the appeal having been filed on the twenty-third day, it was well within time.

facts.text: Flat used by Triveni Kala Sangam, not for original requisition purposes.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, on the facts it is manifest that the flat was number used for any of the purposes for which it was requisitioned for a number of years and indeed, when the Act came into force, it was used only for locating the Triveni Kala Sangam,

issues.text: whether r. 4 is a special law within the meaning of s. 29 (2) of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: In the premises the only question to be decided is whether r. 4 is a special law within the meaning of s. 29 (2) of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: The Letters Patent appeal was within time as it was filed within 30 days from the date of the judgment of Falshaw, J. under r.4

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General, appearing for the appellants, contends, that the Letters Patent appeal, it having been filed within 30 days from the date of the judgment of Falshaw, J., was within time,

arguments.claim: There was sufficient cause for excusing the delay due to fluid state of law on whether Limitation Act or High Court rule governs

anchor.surface_text: and that, in any view, having regard to the fluid state of the law on the question whether the and prescribed by the Limitation Act or the rule by the High Court would govern that appeal, there Was sufficient cause for excusing the delay.

arguments.claim: Requisition continued under 1947 Act s.3 expediently by allotting to Triveni Kala Sangam and deemed under 1952 Act s.24(2) as requisition under s.3 for public purpose of Union which did not cease so no de-requisition

anchor.surface_text: On the merits he argues that the requisition made under r.75-A of the Defence of India Rules  hereinafter called the Rules  was continued unders.3 of the Requisitioned Land  Continuance of Powers  Act, 1947  Act No. 17 of 1947   hereinafter called the 1947 Act , whereunder the appropriate Government was given the power to use or deal with a requisitioned land in such manner as may appear to it to be expedient, that in exercise of the said power the said Government put Triveni Kala Sangam in possession of the same, and that under s.24 2  of the Requisitioning and Acquisitioning of Immovable Property Act, 1952  hereinafter called the 1952 Act , the said requisition shall be deemed to be property requisitioned under s.3 of the said Act and that under the said section the said purpose must be deemed to be a public purpose, being the purpose of the Union and, as that purpose did number cease to exist, the respondents are number entitled to ask for de-requisition of the said flat.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deeming fiction operates only on prior valid requisition for original r.75-A purposes which ceased; cannot validate illegal user diverging from defence purposes; Triveni use not matching

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned counsel for the respondents, seeks to sustain the order of the High Court both on the question of limitation as well as on merits.

arguments.court_reasoning: r.4 prescribes 30 days as special law under s.29(2) Limitation Act

arguments.claim: Case made out for issuing writ of mandamus on merits

anchor.surface_text: They also went into the merits of the case and agreed with Falshaw, J., that a case had been made out for issuing a writ. With the result that the appeal was dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Original requisition purposes under r.75-A ceased; s.6 proviso mandates release

arguments.claim: r.4 is special law under s.29(2) Limitation Act as made under cl.27 Letters Patent

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of the provisions may be stated thus Under cl. 27 of the Letters Patent, the High Court of Judicature of Lahore has the power to make a rule prescribing the period of limitation in respect of appeals from orders made by that Court in exercise of its Original Jurisdiction to a division bench of that High Court. ... In the premises the only question to be decided is whether r. 4 is a special law within the meaning of s. 29 (2) of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: High Court rules under cl.27 Letters Patent constitute special law per precedent

anchor.surface_text: This view was accepted by the Punjab High Court in Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Official Liguidators, punjab Cotton Press Company, Ltd.  in liquidation   1 . There, a full bench of that High Court held that the statutory rules framed by the A.I.R. 1941 Lahore 57  F. B. . High Court under cl. 27 of the Letters Patent under the authority delegated to it by His Majesty who, in turn, was acting under the powers conferred on him by Act of Parliament, are a special law. We agree with this view.

arguments.claim: Under r.75-A(2) expediency limited to purposes in r.75-A(1); cannot requisition on false pretenses

anchor.surface_text: The expediency in the context can only mean expediency in relation to the purposes for which the property was requisitioned. The wide import of the word expedient in Sub-s.  2  must necessarily be limited to the purposes under sub-s.  1  as otherwise we would be attributing to the Legislature an intention to confer a power on the Government to requisition a property on false pretenses.

arguments.claim: 1947 Act s.3 only continues requisition for original r.75-A purposes, does not enlarge powers

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Act was only to continue the. requisition after the expiry of the life of the Defence of India Act and not to enlarge the powers of the Government in respect of the requisitioned land. The land requisitioned under the Ordinance continued to be subject to the requisition. The expression continue clearly brings out the idea that the scope of the section was only to give a further lease of life to the order which otherwise would have expired.

arguments.claim: s.24(2) 1952 Act deeming provision only for prior valid requisitions; cannot validate illegal acts or change original purposes

anchor.surface_text: But the fiction created by s. 24  2  of the Act would operate only upon the requisition already made. The fiction could not validate any illegal act of the Government. Therefore, the question is what was the effect of the earlier requisition under the Rules as well as under the 1947 Act.

arguments.claim: Purpose for which flat requisitioned under r.75-A ceased as used for Triveni Kala Sangam not matching original purposes; s.6 proviso mandates release

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, on the facts it is manifest that the flat was number used for any of the purposes for which it was requisitioned for a number of years and indeed, when the Act came into force, it was used only for locating the Triveni Kala Sangam, ... Under that proviso, where the purposes for which any requisitioned property was being used ceased to exist, the Central Government shall release the property, as soon as may be, from requisition.

arguments.claim: Triveni Kala Sangam use not a public purpose matching original r.75-A; criterion is original purposes not current use under s.3 1952

holdings.text: Rule 4 of the High Court Rules made under clause 27 of the Letters Patent is a special law within the meaning of section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, prescribing a 30-day limitation period for Letters Patent appeals which prevails over Article 151.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 is made by the High Court in exercise of the legislative power conferred upon the said High Court under cl. 27 of the Letters Patent. As the said rule is a law made in respect of special cases covered by it, it would certainly be a special law within the meaning of s. 29 (2) of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court rules under Letters Patent cl.27 constitute special law per s.29(2); confirmed by precedent; harmonious construction with Limitation Act.

holdings.text: The Letters Patent appeal was filed within the 30-day period under Rule 4 and is therefore within time.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that under r. 4 an appeal could be filed within 30 days from the date of the order of Falshaw, J., and the appeal having been filed on the twenty-third day, it was well within time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal filed on 23rd day after excluding certified copies time, within r.4's 30 days as special law.

holdings.text: Expediency under Rule 75-A(2) of Defence of India Rules is limited to purposes specified in Rule 75-A(1) (defence, public safety, etc.).

anchor.surface_text: The expediency in the context can only mean expediency in relation to the purposes for which the property was requisitioned. The wide import of the word expedient in Sub-s. (2) must necessarily be limited to the purposes under sub-s. (1) as otherwise we would be attributing to the Legislature an intention to confer a power on the Government to requisition a property on false pretenses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation prevents requisition on false pretences.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the 1947 Act continues requisition under Rule 75-A for original purposes only and does not enlarge government powers.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Act was only to continue the requisition after the expiry of the life of the Defence of India Act and not to enlarge the powers of the Government in respect of the requisitioned land. The land requisitioned under the Ordinance continued to be subject to the requisition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading of 'continue'; repeats r.75-A(2) language without expansion.

holdings.text: Section 24(2) of the 1952 Act deems prior requisitions valid only if for original Rule 75-A purposes; does not validate illegal use or change purposes.

anchor.surface_text: But the fiction created by s. 24 (2) of the Act would operate only upon the requisition already made. The fiction could not validate any illegal act of the Government. Therefore, the question is what was the effect of the earlier requisition under the Rules as well as under the 1947 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming fiction limited to pre-existing valid requisitions; cannot cure illegality.

holdings.text: The purpose for which the flat was requisitioned ceased as it was used for Triveni Kala Sangam, not for Rule 75-A purposes, triggering mandatory release under proviso to section 6 of 1952 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, on the facts it is manifest that the flat was not used for any of the purposes for which it was requisitioned for a number of years and indeed, when the Act came into force, it was used only for locating the Triveni Kala Sangam, which is clearly, not one of the purposes for which the flat was requisitioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show non-use for original purposes; proviso mandates release when purpose ceases.

holdings.text: Criterion for section 6 proviso is original requisition purpose under Rule 75-A, not current use or any Union purpose under section 3 of 1952 Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes original vs. subsequent use; fiction ties back to r.75-A purposes.

precedents.case_name: Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Official Liquidators, Punjab Cotton Press Company Ltd. (in liquidation)
precedents.cited_proposition: statutory rules framed by the High Court under cl. 27 of the Letters Patent under the authority delegated to it by His Majesty who, in turn, was acting under the powers conferred on him by Act of Parliament, are a special law within the meaning of s. 29(2) of the Limitation Act

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan 1 . 1955 2 S. C. R. 867

anchor.surface_text: In support of this company- tention reliance is placed upon the decision of this companyrt in The State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan  1 . There is a fallacy underlying this argument. The  1  1955 2 S. C. R. 867. effect of the fiction is that the requisition made under r. 75-A of the Rules is a requisition under s. 3 of the 1952 Act, that is, if the requisition was made for purposes mentioned in r. 75-A of the Rules, it would be deemed to be one for a public purpose, being the purpose of the Union, within the meaning of s. 3 of the 1952 Act.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan
precedents.cited_proposition: every Union purpose is a public purpose, being a purpose of the Union within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the 1952 Act

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against High Court order issuing writ of mandamus to restore possession dismissed; High Court order upheld

anchor.surface_text: The expediency in the context can only mean expediency in relation to the purposes for which the property was requisitioned. The wide import of the word expedient in Sub-s. (2) must necessarily be limited to the purposes under sub-s. (1) as otherwise we would be attributing to the Legislature an intention to confer a power on the Government to requisition a property on false pretenses.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: But the fiction created by s. 24 (2) of the Act would operate only upon the requisition already made. The fiction could not validate any illegal act of the Government. Therefore, the question is what was the effect of the earlier requisition under the Rules as well as under the 1947 Act.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, on the facts it is manifest that the flat was not used for any of the purposes for which it was requisitioned for a number of years and indeed, when the Act came into force, it was used only for locating the Triveni Kala Sangam, which is clearly, not one of the purposes for which the flat was requisitioned.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.
